item.title: After Bergdahl Briefing, Senators Still Doubtful on Prisoner Swap
item.description: A closed-door briefing by military officials seemed to do little to defuse the festering political controversy.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN WEISMAN
item.media:description: Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican who was a prisoner of war, said Tuesday the Obama administration’s rationale for the release of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl kept shifting.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Hong Kong Rebel Loses His Trademark Long Hair
item.description: Leung Kwok-hung’s unkempt mane had been a constant in his decade as one of the city’s most animated legislators. That was, until his hair was cut short on Monday.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN WONG

item.title: Egyptian Government Criticized Anew Over Response to Sexual Assaults
item.description: A video showing a mass assault on a woman during a Tahrir Square celebration has stirred new outrage among rape victims and women’s rights advocates.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Taliban Attack Pakistani Airport Again Amid Military Raids
item.description: Gunmen attacked Karachi’s airport for the second time in two days. And the toll from Sunday’s attack rose to at least 37 as seven charred bodies were found in a cold-storage area.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH and SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: Security forces checked a motorbike near an airport training facility in Karachi that was attacked on Tuesday.

item.title: Progress Reported on Cease-Fire Talks on Ukraine
item.description: The foreign ministers of Russia, Germany and Poland said they were optimistic while President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine proposed setting up a corridor to help people flee the violence.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: A pro-Russian fighter guarding a checkpoint in Donetsk, eastern Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: Ireland Investigating Complaints Against Unwed Mother Homes
item.description: The decision to mount an inquiry followed the suggestion that for decades, the remains of 796 children may have been secretly buried at a home.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS DALBY

item.title: Le Pen’s Far-Right Party Eyes Major Status in France, but Voters Are Still Deciding
item.description: Many voters in Bohain-en-Vermandois, a struggling community in the north of France, backed the far-right party in European Parliament elections, but few are ready to herald a switch.
item.dc:creator: By SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: “The new voters, I think we really have them now,” said Armand Pollet, the representative of the far-right National Front in the northern French town of Bohain-en-Vermandois.

item.title: Israeli Parliament Elects Rivlin as New President
item.description: The selection of Reuven Rivlin, a veteran Likud Party politician, ends what was seen as an unseemly race for a largely ceremonial post.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Reuven Rivlin, a veteran Likud Party politician and former Parliament speaker, center, shook hands with the former minister Meir Shitrit at the Knesset in Jerusalem on Tuesday.

item.title: Arms Windfall for Insurgents as Iraq City Falls
item.description: Weapons provided by the Unites States to help Iraqi forces battle militants are now in the hands of the militants.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: After 7 Months, British Hacking Case Heads to Jury
item.description: Rebekah Brooks and Andy Coulson — tabloid editors and former lovers — are accused of condoning the intercepting of voice mails and other practices.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: June 10
item.description: A woman at a protest in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir, seeking the whereabouts of her family member who went missing since a separatist rebellion broke out in the state in 1989.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A demonstration in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir, headed by the Association of Parents of Disappeared Persons, which seeks the whereabouts of people who have disappeared since a separatist rebellion broke out in the state in 1989.

item.title: Letter From the Middle East: Appreciating the Flavors of Palestine
item.description: At a recent dinner at the United States consulate in Jerusalem, a Swiss-born chef was given a challenge of making a menu derived from West Bank food purveyors.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Trial of South Korean Ferry Crew Begins
item.description: Angry relatives of the victims gathered at the courthouse, shouting “Murderer!” as the captain and other senior crew members entered not guilty pleas.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Barentsburg Journal: Ukrainians Find Jobs and a Slice of Russia in Arctic Norway
item.description: Tumult in Ukraine has ensured that there is no shortage of labor on Spitsbergen, a Norwegian island where a Russian company mines coal and Moscow heavily subsidizes aspects of daily life.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Kyrre Lien for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Arctic Coal Trust in Barentsburg is pushing to develop the area as a tourist destination.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Finally, a Pollution Index Beijing Can Love
item.description: A new survey seeks to gauge how open officials are about levels of pollution at the sources of the problem.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: About 66,000 pounds of dead fish were cleared from the Fuhe River in Wuhan, Hubei Province, last fall after the water was polluted with ammonia.

item.title: ‘Friendly Fire’ Strike Kills 5 Special Operations Soldiers in Afghanistan
item.description: The Americans and at least one Afghan soldier were killed when a coalition aircraft accidentally struck their position, Afghan and American officials said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED

item.title: Bosnia’s World Cup Debut Stirs Passions in St. Louis
item.description: A St. Louis neighborhood that seems more European than Midwest is bracing for Bosnia’s first appearance in the World Cup.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN ELIGON
item.media:description: Fans of the Bosnian national soccer team cheering during a recent tune-up against the Ivory Coast in St. Louis.

item.title: Sunni Militants Drive Iraqi Army Out of Mosul
item.description: Soldiers abandoned Iraq’s second-largest city as fighters raided military bases and the governor’s building in one of the most audacious assaults on the government since the U.S. military withdrawal.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By SUADAD AL-SALHY, KAREEM FAHIM and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Iraqis at a checkpoint near the Iraqi city of Arbil on Tuesday. Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki ordered a state of emergency for the entire country.

item.title: India Ink: Police Statements Cloud Alleged Rape and Murder Case, Analysts Say
item.description: Police reform advocates have criticized the contradictory police statements about the alleged rape of two cousins in Uttar Pradesh in May.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: Police officers standing guard on May 31 near a tree where the bodies of two girls were found hanging in Badaun district in Uttar Pradesh on May 31.

item.title: High-Profile Conference to Draw Attention to Sexual Violence in War
item.description: The initiative has drawn support from the movie star Angelina Jolie, Secretary of State John Kerry and the British foreign secretary William Hague.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Arm Syria’s Opposition
item.description: American interests demand that we support the moderate fighters against both Assad and the jihadists.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT S. FORD

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Support for Blind University Aspirant Turns to Censure
item.description: When Li Jinsheng became among the first Chinese blind people to take the regular university entrance examination, he made history. Now he says he failed, and he’s being pilloried.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Li Jinsheng at his massage center in Zhumadian, Henan Province.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Making Naughty in the New India
item.description: The state has many legitimate roles. Regulating sex is not one of them.
item.dc:creator: By SIDDHARTH DHANVANT SHANGHVI

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Artful Dodgers of Brazil
item.description: How an exuberant style of soccer play helped to unify a troubled nation.
item.dc:creator: By OLIVIER GUEZ

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Clerical Rule, Luxury Lifestyle
item.description: Much of Iran’s wealth is in the hands of government officials and their cronies.
item.dc:creator: By SHAHRZAD ELGHANAYAN
